sources.autograph: Lucca, Istituto Musicale Boccherini, D.I.33, 'Sonata a quattro no. 4...' Probably a copy, but extremely interesting on account of the detailed accuracy with which the text, the slurs and the expression-marks are recorded. Is it possible that these details are in the hand of Boccherini? In any case, the MS. appears to have been copied from Boccherini's original MS.

A most interesting manuscript, of which the text is identical to that of the manuscript in Lucca, although the order of the works is different. The cover has a note 'Per S.A.R. entries.notes: The same quartet begins with a Largo. I presume that the Largo is merely a brief introduction which was suppressed when the work was engraved, without anything being put in its place. The MS. at Lucca (D.I.33) confirms the hypothesis put forward by Picquot. The Allegro assai is certainly by Boccherini, and it is preceded by a Largo of ten bars. A conscientious performance of this quartet should therefore take account of this MS. and not merely play the text of the Vénier edition, which deprives the work of a lyrical episode forming a natural prelude to the feverish Allegro of the first movement.

entries.notes: The composition of these quartets, which mark an important date in the evolution of Boccherini's style, must have been spread over a relatively long period. The date on the MS. has been scratched out by Boccherini himself. He first wrote 'op. 111e de 1776' and then altered this to 'op. 12e de 1777'. Eventually, when he drew up a thematic catalogue of his works, he listed these quartets under the year 1778 with the number Op. 24. We do not know the reason for these changes; but the first date makes it clear that the six works were composed—if not in their final form, at least in their general spirit—as early as the middle of the year 1776.

entries.notes: The origin of the title 'La Tiranna' is unknown. There is no doubt that the words are in the hand of Boccherini. Titles of this kind are so rare that we may be sure that they denote a precise intention on the part of the composer. Two or three explanations have been suggested for the present title. Some say that it is borrowed from a work by Goya, the portrait (now in the Academia de Bellas Artes in Madrid) of the actress Rosario Fernandez, who was known as 'La Tirana'. According to others, it is a reference to 'la tirana', the name of a popular dance and also of a slow melody; the trio of the minuet corresponds well to this last explanation. What is certain is the very Spanish character of the work, with a strong contrast between the nervous vivacity of the Presto and the sombre melancholy of the minuet. Unpublished in Boccherini's life-time.

sources.autograph: Washington, Library of Congress, M432. A2. B68. Op. 64 Case. '1804. Opera 64. Sei quartetti per due violini, viola e violoncello composti espressamente per il cittadino Luciano Bonaparte da Luigi Boccherini. Quartetto primo'.

entries.notes: The Washington MS. with the above number is described as a copy, but this is incorrect. There is no doubt whatever that this is the autograph MS., not recognised as such since 1832, the year in which Picquot saw it for the last time in the collection of the successor of Janet et Cotelle. Although the title speaks of six quartets, only the first quartet was completed and the first movement of the second. Boccherini, already very ill, had not the strength to proceed further. After his death his sons failed to find any draft of the quartets which should have followed.

entries.additional_notes: At the beginning of this MS. is the following note (19th century) in English: 'N.B.—This manuscript is very correctly and carefully written, and may possibly be the hand writing of Dr Haydn; 1st from the close resemblance to his style as recorded, and 2ndly from the constant intercourse between these two eminent composers transmission to each other of their works (sic)'. The tradition that close relations existed between Haydn and Boccherini is discussed in the Biography (p. 45). With regard to the present MS. we have consulted two scholars with a special knowledge of Haydn, Messrs. Anthony van Hoboken and Karl Geiringer. The opinion of both is that the handwriting of the score of these six quartets, though very similar to that of Haydn, is not his nor that of any of his regular amanuenses. Moreover, there is no known instance of Haydn having arranged a series of works by another musician, even a friend. Whoever transcribed the score appears to have added certain words (though not the note quoted above) in English, and we are inclined to believe that the arrangements are the work of an English amateur of the beginning of the 19th century. Unpublished.

entries.notes: Arrangements. No reference in Boccherini's autograph catalogue. For comment as to authenticity, see below. It appears that Boyer-Naderman published two books of three quartets for flute, violin, viola and 'cello, but no copy of this edition has been found. We can only refer to the comment of Picquot (p. 142): 'The early quartets of Boccherini have furnished the framework for these works without merit, in which a flute part has been substituted, by way of transposition, for the part of the first violin. This completely distorts the character and effect of the works'.

entries.notes: Although the title announces six quartets, only three were published in this edition. The other three are probably those published by Bouillon (see No. 264), since the Bouillon edition is described in the title as 'Livre 3ème', Books 1 and 2 being presumably Nos. 262 and 263.

entries.title: THREE QUARTETS (nos. 7 to 9) for clarinet, flute, horn and bassoon

first_edition.title: Trois quatuors pour flûte, clarinette, cor et basson extraits des oeuvres de Boccherini dédiés à Monsieur Camille Canuel, Avocat, par Othon Van den Broek pensionnaire de la Chapelle du Roi et de l'Académie Royale de musique, Livre 3ème, à Paris, chez Bouillon, rue du Doyenné nº 12

entries.notes: None of these movements corresponds to any movement of a known work by Boccherini. It is impossible to reach any conclusion as to the origin of these arrangements. Were they derived by Van den Broek from manuscripts or editions of works by Boccherini—or falsely attributed to Boccherini—which are unknown to us? Or did he perhaps wish to give the prestige of Boccherini's name to works of his own production? In any case, it may be remarked that the musical value of this third collection is very inferior to that of the two preceding books (Nos. 262 and 263).
